props.name: when
props.docs:
A player query string that determines when the UI should be displayed. The special string
'never' will indicate that the UI should never be displayed.

props.name: smallWhen
props.docs:
A player query string that determines when the small (e.g., mobile) UI should be displayed. The
special string 'never' will indicate that the small device optimized UI should never be
displayed.

props.name: thumbnails
props.docs:
The absolute or relative URL to a [WebVTT](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebVTT_API)
file resource.

props.name: customIcons
props.docs:
Whether the default icons should _not_ be loaded. Set this to `true` when providing your own
icons.

props.name: translations
props.docs: Translation map from english to your desired language for words used throughout the layout.

props.name: menuGroup
props.docs:
Specifies whether menu buttons should be placed in the top or bottom controls group. This
only applies to the large video layout.

props.name: noModal
props.docs:
Whether modal menus should be disabled when the small layout is active. A modal menu is
a floating panel that floats up from the bottom of the screen (outside of the player). It's
enabled by default as it provides a better user experience for touch devices.

components.name: DefaultAudioLayout
components.docs:
The audio layout is our production-ready UI that's displayed when the media view type is set to
'audio'. It includes support for audio tracks, slider chapters, and captions out of the box. It
doesn't support live streams just yet.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-match - Whether this layout is being used (query match).

'never' will indicate that the UI should never be displayed.

props.name: smallWhen

special string 'never' will indicate that the small device optimized UI should never be

components.name: DefaultVideoLayout
components.docs:
The video layout is our production-ready UI that's displayed when the media view type is set to
'video'. It includes support for picture-in-picture, fullscreen, slider chapters, slider
previews, captions, and audio/quality settings out of the box. It doesn't support live
streams just yet.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-match - Whether this layout is being used (query match).

components.name: MediaPlayer
components.docs:
All media elements exist inside the `<media-player>` component. This component's main
responsibilities are to manage media state updates, dispatch media events, handle media
requests, and expose media state through HTML attributes and CSS properties for styling
purposes.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-autoplay-error - Autoplay has failed to start.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-buffering - Media is not ready for playback or waiting for more data.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-can-load - Media can now begin loading.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-can-play - Media is ready for playback.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-captions - Captions are available and visible.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-live-edge - Playback is at the live edge.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-loop - Media is set to replay on end.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-playsinline - Media should play inline by default (iOS).

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-pointer - The user's pointer device type (coarse/fine).

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-preview - The user is interacting with the time slider.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-seeking - User is seeking to a new playback position.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-waiting - Media is waiting for more data to resume playback.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-focus - Whether player is being keyboard focused.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-hocus - Whether player is being keyboard focused or hovered over.

props.name: crossorigin
props.docs:
Defines how the media element handles cross-origin requests, thereby enabling the
configuration of the CORS requests for the element's fetched data.

props.name: src

type.full: MediaResource | { src: MediaResource; type?: string; } | { src: MediaResource; type?: string; }[]

props.docs: The URL and optionally type of the current media resource/s to be considered for playback.

props.name: logLevel
props.docs:
The current log level. Values in order of priority are: `silent`, `error`, `warn`, `info`,
and `debug`.

props.name: load
props.docs:
Indicates when the provider can begin loading media.

- `eager`: media will be loaded immediately.
- `idle`: media will be loaded after the page has loaded and `requestIdleCallback` is fired.
- `visible`: media will delay loading until the provider has entered the viewport.
- `custom`: media will wait for the `startLoading()` method or `media-start-loading` event.

props.name: controlsDelay
props.docs:
The default amount of delay in milliseconds while media playback is progressing without user
activity to indicate an idle state and hide controls.

props.name: fullscreenOrientation
props.docs:
This method will indicate the orientation to lock the screen to when in fullscreen mode and
the Screen Orientation API is available.

props.name: preferNativeHLS
props.docs:
Whether native HLS support is preferred over using `hls.js`. We recommend setting this to
`false` to ensure a consistent and configurable experience across browsers. In addition, our
live stream support and DVR detection is much better with `hls.js` so choose accordingly.

This should generally only be set to `true` if (1) you're working with HLS streams, and (2)
you want AirPlay to work via the native Safari controls (i.e., `controls` attribute is
present on the `<media-player>` element).

props.name: keyDisabled
props.docs:
Whether keyboard support is disabled for the media player globally. This property won't disable
standard ARIA keyboard controls for individual components when focused.

props.name: keyTarget
props.docs:
The target on which to listen for keyboard events (e.g., `keydown`):

- `document`: the player will listen for events on the entire document. In the case that
multiple players are on the page, only the most recently active player will receive input.
- `player`: the player will listen for events on the player itself or one of its children
were recently interacted with.

props.name: keyShortcuts
props.docs:
Extends global media player keyboard shortcuts. The shortcuts can be specified as a
space-separated list of combinations (e.g., `p Control+Space`), see the provided doc link
for more information.

Do note, if `aria-keyshortcuts` is specified on a component then it will take precedence
over the respective value set here.

doctags.name: example
doctags.text:
```js
keyShortcuts = {
  togglePaused: 'k Space',
  toggleMuted: 'm',
  toggleFullscreen: 'f',
  togglePictureInPicture: 'i',
  toggleCaptions: 'c',
  seekBackward: 'ArrowLeft',
  seekForward: 'ArrowRight',
  volumeUp: 'ArrowUp',
  volumeDown: 'ArrowDown',
}
```

props.name: autoplay
props.docs:
Whether playback should automatically begin as soon as enough media is available to do so
without interruption.

Sites which automatically play audio (or videos with an audio track) can be an unpleasant
experience for users, so it should be avoided when possible. If you must offer autoplay
functionality, you should make it opt-in (requiring a user to specifically enable it).

However, autoplay can be useful when creating media elements whose source will be set at a
later time, under user control.

props.name: controls
props.docs:
Indicates whether a user interface should be shown for controlling the resource. Set this to
`false` when you want to provide your own custom controls, and `true` if you want the current
provider to supply its own default controls. Depending on the provider, changing this prop
may cause the player to completely reset.

props.name: currentTime
props.docs:
A `double` indicating the current playback time in seconds. Defaults to `0` if the media has
not started to play and has not seeked. Setting this value seeks the media to the new
time. The value can be set to a minimum of `0` and maximum of the total length of the
media (indicated by the duration prop).

props.name: loop
props.docs:
Whether media should automatically start playing from the beginning (replay) every time
it ends.

props.name: muted
props.docs: Whether the audio is muted or not.

props.name: paused
props.docs:
Whether playback should be paused. Defaults to `true` if no media has loaded or playback has
not started. Setting this to `false` will begin/resume playback.

props.name: playsinline
props.docs:
Whether the video is to be played "inline", that is within the element's playback area. Note
that setting this to `false` does not imply that the video will always be played in fullscreen.
Depending on the provider, changing this prop may cause the player to completely reset.

props.name: poster
props.docs:
The URL of the current poster. Defaults to `''` if no media/poster has been given or
loaded.

props.name: preload
props.docs:
Configures the preload setting of the underlying media provider once it can load (see
`loading` property).

The `preload` attribute provides a hint to the browser about what the author thinks will
lead to the best user experience with regards to what content is loaded before the video is
played. The recommended default is `metadata`.

props.name: playbackRate
props.docs:
Sets the rate at which the media is being played back. This is used to implement user
controls for fast forward, slow motion, and so forth. The normal playback rate is multiplied
by this value to obtain the current rate, so a value of 1.0 indicates normal speed.

Examples:

- `0.5` = slow down to 50% of the normal speed
- `1.5` = speed up normal speed by 50%
- `2` = double the normal speed

props.name: title
props.docs: The title of the current media.

props.name: viewType
props.docs:
The type of player view that should be used (i.e., audio or video). By default this is set
to `video`.

props.name: volume
props.docs: An `int` between `0` (silent) and `1` (loudest) indicating the audio volume. Defaults to `1`.

props.name: streamType
props.docs:
The current media stream type. This value helps determine what type of UI should be
displayed and whether seeking operations are permitted during live streams. If seeking
is permitted, set this value to `live:dvr` or `ll-live:dvr`.

props.name: liveEdgeTolerance
props.docs:
The number of seconds that `currentTime` can be behind `liveEdgeStart` and still be considered
at the edge. The default value is 10, meaning the user can be up to 10 seconds behind the
live edge start and still be considered live.

props.name: minLiveDVRWindow
props.docs: The minimum seekable length in seconds before seeking operations are permitted.

events.name: media-player-connect
events.docs: Fired when the player element `<media-player>` connects to the DOM.

events.name: audio-tracks-change
events.docs: Fired when an audio track has been added or removed.

events.name: audio-track-change
events.docs: Fired when the current audio track changes.

events.name: autoplay-change
events.docs: Fired when the `autoplay` property has changed value.

events.name: autoplay-fail
events.docs:
Fired when an autoplay attempt has failed. The event detail contains the error that
had occurred on the last autoplay attempt which caused it to fail.

events.name: can-load
events.docs:
Fired when the provider can begin loading media. This depends on the type of `loading`
that has been configured. The `eager` strategy will be immediate, and `lazy` once the provider
has entered the viewport.

events.name: can-play-through
events.docs:
Fired when the user agent can play the media, and estimates that **enough** data has been
loaded to play the media up to its end without having to stop for further buffering of content.

events.name: can-play
events.docs:
Fired when the user agent can play the media, but estimates that **not enough** data has been
loaded to play the media up to its end without having to stop for further buffering of content.

events.name: controls-change
events.docs:
Fired when controls visibility changes. The controls are idle/hidden when playback is
progressing (playing), and there is no user activity for a set period of time
(default is 2.5s). The event detail contains whether the controls are visible or not.

events.name: duration-change
events.docs: Fired when the `duration` property changes.

events.name: fullscreen-change
events.docs:
Fired when media enters/exits fullscreen. The event detail is a `boolean` indicating
if fullscreen was entered (`true`) or exited (`false`).

events.name: fullscreen-error
events.docs:
Fired when an error occurs either entering or exiting fullscreen. This will generally occur
if fullscreen is not supported or the user has not interacted with the page yet.

events.name: live-change
events.docs:
Fired when the `live` state changes. The event detail indicates whether the current stream
is live or not.

events.name: live-edge-change
events.docs:
Fired when the `liveEdge` state changes. The event detail indicates whether the user is viewing
at the live edge or not.

events.name: load-start
events.docs: Fired when the browser has started to load a resource.

events.name: loaded-data
events.docs:
Fired when the frame at the current playback position of the media has finished loading; often
the first frame.

events.name: loaded-metadata
events.docs: Fired when the metadata has been loaded.

events.name: loop-change
events.docs: Fired when the `loop` property has changed value.

events.name: media-type-change
events.docs: Fired when the `media` property changes value.

events.name: orientation-change
events.docs: Fired when a screen orientation change is requested on or by the media.

events.name: play-fail
events.docs: Fired when an attempt to start media playback results in an error.

events.name: playsinline-change
events.docs: Fired when the `playsinline` property has changed value.

events.name: poster-change
events.docs: Fired when the `currentPoster` property has changed value.

events.name: provider-change
events.docs:
Fired when the new media provider has been selected. This will be `null` if no provider is
able to play one of the current sources.

This event is ideal for initially configuring any provider-specific settings.

events.name: provider-loader-change
events.docs:
Fired when the new media provider loader has been selected and rendered. This will be `null` if
no loader is able to play one of the current sources.

events.name: provider-setup
events.docs:
Fired immediately after the provider has been set up. Do not try and configure the provider
here as it'll be too late - prefer the `provider-change` event.

events.name: picture-in-picture-change
events.docs:
Fired when media enters/exits picture-in-picture (PIP) mode. The event detail is a `boolean`
indicating if PIP was entered (`true`) or exited (`false`).

events.name: picture-in-picture-error
events.docs:
Fired when an error occurs either entering or exiting picture-in-picture (PIP) mode. This will
generally occur if PIP is not supported or the user has not interacted with the page yet.

events.name: qualities-change
events.docs: Fired when the list of available video qualities/renditions has changed.

events.name: quality-change
events.docs:
Fired when the current video quality/rendition has changed. The event detail will be null if
video quality information is not available.

events.name: rate-change
events.docs: Fired when the playback rate has changed. The event `detail` contains the new rate.

events.name: source-change
events.docs: Fired when the `source` property has changed value.

events.name: sources-change
events.docs: Fired when the current media sources has changed.

events.name: time-update
events.docs:
Fired when the `currentTime` property value changes due to media playback or the
user seeking.

events.name: stream-type-change
events.docs:
Fired when the `streamType` property changes value. The event detail contains the type of
stream (e.g., `on-demand`, `live`, `live:dvr`, etc.).

events.name: text-tracks-change
events.docs: Fired when an audio track has been added or removed.

events.name: text-track-change
events.docs: Fired when the current captions/subtitles text track changes.

events.name: view-type-change
events.docs:
Fired when the `viewType` property changes value. This will generally fire when the
new provider has mounted and determined what type of player view is appropriate given
the type of media it can play.

events.name: volume-change
events.docs: Fired when the `volume` or `muted` properties change value.

events.name: abort
events.docs: Fired when the resource was not fully loaded, but not as the result of an error.

events.name: autoplay
events.docs:
Fired when an autoplay attempt has successfully been made (ie: media playback has automatically
started). The event detail whether media is `muted` before any attempts are made.

events.name: destroy
events.docs: Fired when the player is manually destroyed by calling the `destroy()` method.

events.name: emptied
events.docs: Fired when the media has become empty.

events.name: end
events.docs:
Fired each time media playback has reached the end. This is fired even if the
`loop` property is `true`, which is generally when you'd reach for this event over the
`MediaEndedEvent` if you want to be notified of media looping.

events.name: ended
events.docs:
Fired when playback or streaming has stopped because the end of the media was reached or
because no further data is available. This is not fired if playback will start from the
beginning again due to the `loop` property being `true` (see `MediaReplayEvent`
and `MediaEndEvent`).

events.name: error
events.docs:
Fired when media loading or playback has encountered any issues (for example, a network
connectivity problem). The event detail contains a potential message containing more
information about the error (empty string if nothing available), and a code that identifies
the general type of error that occurred.

events.name: pause
events.docs:
Fired when a request to `pause` an activity is handled and the activity has entered its
`paused` state, most commonly after the media has been paused through a call to the
`pause()` method.

events.name: play
events.docs:
Fired when the `paused` property is changed from `true` to `false`, as a result of the `play()`
method, or the `autoplay` attribute.

events.name: playing
events.docs: Fired when playback is ready to start after having been paused or delayed due to lack of data.

events.name: progress
events.docs: Fired periodically as the browser loads a resource.

events.name: replay
events.docs:
Fired when media playback starts again after being in an `ended` state. This is fired
when the `loop` property is `true` and media loops, whereas the `play` event is not.

events.name: seeked
events.docs:
Fired when a seek operation completed, the current playback position has changed, and the
`seeking` property is changed to `false`.

events.name: seeking
events.docs:
Fired when a seek operation starts, meaning the seeking property has changed to `true` and the
media is seeking to a new position.

events.name: stalled
events.docs:
Fired when the user agent is trying to fetch media data, but data is unexpectedly not
forthcoming.

events.name: started
events.docs:
Fired when media playback has just started, in other words the at the moment the following
happens: `currentTime > 0`.

events.name: suspend
events.docs: Fired when media data loading has been suspended.

events.name: waiting
events.docs: Fired when playback has stopped because of a temporary lack of data.

events.name: media-audio-track-change-request
events.docs:
Fired when requesting to change the current audio track to the given index in the
`AudioTrackList` on the player.

events.name: media-enter-fullscreen-request
events.docs:
Fired when requesting media to enter fullscreen. The event `detail` can specify the
fullscreen target, which can be the media or provider (defaults to `prefer-media`).

events.name: media-exit-fullscreen-request
events.docs:
Fired when requesting media to exit fullscreen. The event `detail` can specify the fullscreen
target, which can be the media or provider (defaults to `prefer-media`).

events.name: media-enter-pip-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting media to enter picture-in-picture mode.

events.name: media-exit-pip-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting media to exit picture-in-picture mode.

events.name: media-live-edge-request
events.docs:
Fired when requesting media to seek to the live edge (i.e., set the current time to the current
live time).

events.name: media-loop-request
events.docs:
Internal event that is fired by a media provider when requesting media playback to restart after
reaching the end. This event also helps notify the player that media will be looping.

events.name: media-mute-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting the media to be muted.

events.name: media-pause-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting media playback to temporarily stop.

events.name: media-pause-controls-request
events.docs:
Fired when controls visibility tracking should pause. This is typically used when a control
is being actively interacted with, and we don't want the controls to be hidden before
the interaction is complete (eg: scrubbing, or settings is open).

events.name: media-play-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting media playback to begin/resume.

events.name: media-quality-change-request
events.docs:
Fired when requesting to change the current video quality to the given index in the
`VideoQualityList` on the player.

events.name: media-rate-change-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting to change the current playback rate.

events.name: media-resume-controls-request
events.docs:
Fired when controls visibility tracking may resume. This is typically called after requesting
tracking to pause via `media-pause-controls-request`.

events.name: media-seek-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting a time change. In other words, moving the play head to a new position.

events.name: media-seeking-request
events.docs: Fired when seeking/scrubbing to a new playback position.

events.name: media-start-loading
events.docs:
Fired when requesting media to begin loading. This will only take effect if the `loading`
strategy on the provider is set to `custom`.

events.name: media-text-track-change-request
events.docs:
Fired when requesting to change the `mode` on a text track at the given index in the
`TextTrackList` on the player.

events.name: media-unmute-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting the media to be unmuted.

events.name: media-volume-change-request
events.docs: Fired when requesting the media volume to be set to a new level.

events.name: video-presentation-change
events.docs: Fired when the video presentation mode changes. Only available in Safari.

events.name: hls-lib-load-start
events.docs: Fired when the browser begins downloading the `hls.js` library.

events.name: hls-lib-loaded
events.docs: Fired when the `hls.js` library has been loaded.

events.name: hls-lib-load-error
events.docs: Fired when the `hls.js` library fails during the download process.

events.name: hls-instance
events.docs:
Fired when the `hls.js` instance is built. This will not fire if the browser does not
support `hls.js`.

events.name: hls-unsupported
events.docs:
Fired when the browser doesn't support HLS natively, _and_ `hls.js` doesn't support
this environment either, most likely due to missing Media Extensions or video codecs.

events.name: hls-media-attaching
events.docs: Fired before `MediaSource` begins attaching to the media element.

events.name: hls-media-attached
events.docs: Fired when `MediaSource` has been successfully attached to the media element.

events.name: hls-media-detaching
events.docs: Fired before detaching `MediaSource` from the media element.

events.name: hls-media-detached
events.docs: Fired when `MediaSource` has been detached from media element.

events.name: hls-buffer-reset
events.docs: Fired when we buffer is going to be reset.

events.name: hls-buffer-codecs
events.docs: Fired when we know about the codecs that we need buffers for to push into.

events.name: hls-buffer-created
events.docs: Fired when `SourceBuffer`'s have been created.

events.name: hls-buffer-appending
events.docs: Fired when we begin appending a media segment to the buffer.

events.name: hls-buffer-appended
events.docs: Fired when we are done with appending a media segment to the buffer.

events.name: hls-buffer-eos
events.docs:
Fired when the stream is finished and we want to notify the media buffer that there will be no
more data.

events.name: hls-buffer-flushing
events.docs: Fired when the media buffer should be flushed.

events.name: hls-buffer-flushed
events.docs: Fired when the media buffer has been flushed.

events.name: hls-manifest-loading
events.docs: Fired to signal that manifest loading is starting.

events.name: hls-manifest-loaded
events.docs: Fired after the manifest has been loaded.

events.name: hls-manifest-parsed
events.docs: Fired after manifest has been parsed.

events.name: hls-level-switching
events.docs: Fired when a level switch is requested.

events.name: hls-level-switched
events.docs: Fired when a level switch is effective.

events.name: hls-level-loading
events.docs: Fired when a level playlist loading starts.

events.name: hls-level-loaded
events.docs: Fired when a level playlist loading finishes.

events.name: hls-level-updated
events.docs:
Fired when a level's details have been updated based on previous details, after it has been
loaded.

events.name: hls-level-pts-updated
events.docs: Fired when a level's PTS information has been updated after parsing a fragment.

events.name: hls-levels-updated
events.docs: Fired when a level is removed after calling `removeLevel()`.

events.name: hls-audio-tracks-updated
events.docs: Fired to notify that the audio track list has been updated.

events.name: hls-audio-track-switching
events.docs: Fired when an audio track switching is requested.

events.name: hls-audio-track-switched
events.docs: Fired when an audio track switch actually occurs.

events.name: hls-audio-track-loading
events.docs: Fired when loading an audio track starts.

events.name: hls-audio-track-loaded
events.docs: Fired when loading an audio track finishes.

events.name: hls-subtitle-tracks-updated
events.docs: Fired to notify that the subtitle track list has been updated.

events.name: hls-subtitle-tracks-cleared
events.docs: Fired to notify that subtitle tracks were cleared as a result of stopping the media.

events.name: hls-subtitle-track-switch
events.docs: Fired when a subtitle track switch occurs.

events.name: hls-subtitle-track-loading
events.docs: Fired when loading a subtitle track starts.

events.name: hls-subtitle-track-loaded
events.docs: Fired when loading a subtitle track finishes.

events.name: hls-subtitle-frag-processed
events.docs: Fired when a subtitle fragment has been processed.

events.name: hls-cues-parsed
events.docs: Fired when a set of `VTTCue`'s to be managed externally has been parsed.

events.name: hls-non-native-text-tracks-found
events.docs: Fired when a text track to be managed externally is found.

events.name: hls-init-pts-found
events.docs: Fired when the first timestamp is found.

events.name: hls-frag-loading
events.docs: Fired when loading a fragment starts.

events.name: hls-frag-load-emergency-aborted
events.docs: Fired when fragment loading is aborted for emergency switch down.

events.name: hls-frag-loaded
events.docs: Fired when fragment loading is completed.

events.name: hls-frag-decrypted
events.docs: Fired when a fragment has finished decrypting.

events.name: hls-frag-parsing-init-segment
events.docs: Fired when `InitSegment` has been extracted from a fragment.

events.name: hls-frag-parsing-userdata
events.docs: Fired when parsing sei text is completed.

events.name: hls-frag-parsing-metadata
events.docs: Fired when parsing id3 is completed.

events.name: hls-frag-parsed
events.docs: Fired when fragment parsing is completed.

events.name: hls-frag-buffered-data
events.docs: Fired when fragment remuxed MP4 boxes have all been appended into `SourceBuffer`.

events.name: hls-frag-changed
events.docs: Fired when fragment matching with current media position is changing.

events.name: hls-fps-drop
events.docs: Fired when a FPS drop is identified.

events.name: hls-fps-drop-level-capping
events.docs: Fired when FPS drop triggers auto level capping.

events.name: hls-error
events.docs: Fired when an error has occurred during loading or playback.

events.name: hls-destroying
events.docs:
Fired when the `hls.js` instance is being destroyed. Different from `hls-media-detached` as
one could want to detach, and reattach media to the `hls.js` instance to handle mid-rolls.

events.name: hls-key-loading
events.docs: Fired when a decrypt key loading starts.

events.name: hls-key-loaded
events.docs: Fired when a decrypt key has been loaded.

events.name: hls-back-buffer-reached
events.docs: Fired when the back buffer is reached as defined by the `backBufferLength` config option.

state.name: autoplay
state.docs:
Whether playback should automatically begin as soon as enough media is available to do so
without interruption.

Sites which automatically play audio (or videos with an audio track) can be an unpleasant
experience for users, so it should be avoided when possible. If you must offer autoplay
functionality, you should make it opt-in (requiring a user to specifically enable it).

However, autoplay can be useful when creating media elements whose source will be set at a
later time, under user control.

state.name: autoplayError
state.docs:
Set to an error when autoplay has failed to begin playback. This can be used to determine
when to show a recovery UI in the event autoplay fails.

state.name: buffered
state.docs:
Returns a `TimeRanges` object that indicates the ranges of the media source that the
browser has buffered (if any) at the moment the buffered property is accessed. This is usually
contiguous but if the user jumps about while media is buffering, it may contain holes.

state.name: bufferedStart
state.docs:
The earliest time in seconds for which media has been buffered (i.e., downloaded by the
browser).

state.name: bufferedEnd
state.docs:
The latest time in seconds for which media has been buffered (i.e., downloaded by the
browser).

state.name: duration
state.docs:
A `double` indicating the total playback length of the media in seconds. If no media data is
available, the returned value is `0`. If the media is of indefinite length (such as
streamed live media, a WebRTC call's media, or similar), the value is `+Infinity`.

state.name: canFullscreen
state.docs:
Whether the native browser fullscreen API is available, or the current provider can
toggle fullscreen mode. This does not mean that the operation is guaranteed to be successful,
only that it can be attempted.

state.name: canPictureInPicture
state.docs: Whether picture-in-picture mode is supported by the current media provider.

state.name: canLoad
state.docs:
Whether media is allowed to begin loading. This depends on the `loading` configuration.
If `eager`, `canLoad` will be `true` immediately, and if `lazy` this will become `true`
once the media has entered the viewport.

state.name: canPlay
state.docs:
Whether the user agent can play the media, but estimates that **not enough** data has been
loaded to play the media up to its end without having to stop for further buffering of
content.

state.name: canSeek
state.docs:
Whether seeking operations are possible on the current stream. This generally false for
live streams that are loaded natively.

state.name: controls
state.docs:
Indicates whether a user interface should be shown for controlling the resource. Set this to
`false` when you want to provide your own custom controls, and `true` if you want the current
provider to supply its own default controls. Depending on the provider, changing this prop
may cause the player to completely reset.

state.name: crossorigin
state.docs:
Defines how the media element handles cross-origin requests, thereby enabling the
configuration of the CORS requests for the element's fetched data.

state.name: poster
state.docs:
The URL of the current poster. Defaults to `''` if no media/poster has been given or
loaded.

state.name: currentTime
state.docs:
A `double` indicating the current playback time in seconds. Defaults to `0` if the media has
not started to play and has not seeked. Setting this value seeks the media to the new
time. The value can be set to a minimum of `0` and maximum of the total length of the
media (indicated by the duration prop).

state.name: ended
state.docs:
Whether media playback has reached the end. In other words it'll be true
if `currentTime === duration`.

state.name: error
state.docs:
Contains the most recent media error or undefined if there's been none. You can listen for
`error` event updates and examine this object to debug further.

state.name: fullscreen
state.docs: Whether the player is currently in fullscreen mode.

state.name: controlsVisible
state.docs:
Whether the controls are visible. By default, controls will be hidden when media playback
is progressing (playing) without any detected user activity for a set period of time
(default is 2.5s).

state.name: userBehindLiveEdge
state.docs:
Whether the user has intentionally seeked behind the live edge. The user must've seeked
roughly 2 or more seconds behind during a live stream for this to be considered true.

state.name: loop
state.docs:
Whether media should automatically start playing from the beginning (replay) every time
it ends.

state.name: logLevel
state.docs:
The current log level. Values in order of priority are: `silent`, `error`, `warn`, `info`,
and `debug`.

state.name: live
state.docs: Whether the current media stream is live (i.e., being broadcast right now).

state.name: liveEdgeTolerance
state.docs:
The number of seconds that `currentTime` can be behind `liveEdgeStart` and still be considered
at the edge. The default value is 10, meaning the user can be up to 10 seconds behind the
live edge start and still be considered live.

state.name: minLiveDVRWindow
state.docs: The minimum seekable length in seconds before seeking operations are permitted.

state.name: liveEdge
state.docs:
Whether the current stream is at the live edge. This is true if:

1. The player is _not_ in a paused state.
2. The user has _not_ intentionally seeked behind live edge start.
3. The `currentTime` is greater or equal than `liveEdgeStart`.

This value will default to `false` for non-live streams.

state.name: liveEdgeStart
state.docs:
This is the starting edge of the live stream.

A delay is applied in `hls.js` that's specified by the `liveSyncDurationCount` which is
expressed as a multiple of `EXT-X-TARGETDURATION` (default value is safely set to 3). If
set to `m`, playback will start from the fragment at `n-m`, where `n` is the last fragment
of the live playlist. Decreasing this value is likely to cause playback stalls.

The `seekableEnd` value is used as the live edge start in native playback engines.

state.name: liveEdgeWindow
state.docs:
The length of the live edge window in seconds starting from `liveEdgeStart` and ending at
`seekableEnd`. If the `duration` of the stream is `Infinity` or the stream is non-live then
this value will default to 0.

state.name: mediaType
state.docs:
The type of media that is currently active, whether it's audio or video. Defaults
to `unknown` when no media has been loaded or the type cannot be determined.

state.name: muted
state.docs: Whether the audio is muted or not.

state.name: paused
state.docs:
Whether playback should be paused. Defaults to `true` if no media has loaded or playback has
not started. Setting this to `false` will begin/resume playback.

state.name: played
state.docs: Contains the ranges of the media source that the browser has played, if any.

state.name: playing
state.docs:
Whether media is actively playing back. Defaults to `false` if no media has
loaded or playback has not started.

state.name: playsinline
state.docs:
Whether the video is to be played "inline", that is within the element's playback area. Note
that setting this to `false` does not imply that the video will always be played in fullscreen.
Depending on the provider, changing this prop may cause the player to completely reset.

state.name: playbackRate
state.docs:
Sets the rate at which the media is being played back. This is used to implement user
controls for fast forward, slow motion, and so forth. The normal playback rate is multiplied
by this value to obtain the current rate, so a value of 1.0 indicates normal speed.

Examples:

- `0.5` = slow down to 50% of the normal speed
- `1.5` = speed up normal speed by 50%
- `2` = double the normal speed

state.name: pictureInPicture
state.docs: Whether the player is currently in picture-in-picture mode.

state.name: preload
state.docs:
Configures the preload setting of the underlying media provider once it can load (see
`loading` property).

The `preload` attribute provides a hint to the browser about what the author thinks will
lead to the best user experience with regards to what content is loaded before the video is
played. The recommended default is `metadata`.

state.name: autoQuality
state.docs: Whether auto quality selection is active.

state.name: qualities
state.docs:
The list of available video qualities/renditions. This will be empty if quality information
is not provided by the current media provider.

state.name: quality
state.docs:
The current playback quality. This will be `null` if quality information is not provided
by the current media provider.

state.name: audioTracks
state.docs:
The list of available audio tracks. This will be empty if audio track information is not
provided by the current media provider.

state.name: audioTrack
state.docs:
The current audio track. This will be `null` if audio track information is not provided by
 the current media provider.

state.name: canSetQuality
state.docs:
Whether the current video quality list is read-only, meaning quality selections can only
be set internally by the media provider. This will only be `true` when working with particular
third-party embeds such as YouTube.

state.name: canSetVolume
state.docs:
Whether the current volume can be changed. This depends on the current provider and browser
environment. It will generally be `false` on mobile devices as it's set by system controls.

state.name: seekable
state.docs:
Contains the time ranges that the user is able to seek to, if any. This tells us which parts
of the media can be played without delay; this is irrespective of whether that part has
been downloaded or not.

Some parts of the media may be seekable but not buffered if byte-range
requests are enabled on the server. Byte range requests allow parts of the media file to
be delivered from the server and so can be ready to play almost immediately — thus they are
seekable.

state.name: seekableStart
state.docs:
Contains the earliest time in seconds at which media can be seeked to. Generally this is
zero, but for live streams it may start at a non-zero value.

state.name: seekableEnd
state.docs:
The latest time in seconds at which media can be seeked to. This will default to `Infinity`
if no seekable range is found. If byte-range requests are enabled on the server this should
be equal to the media duration - note for live streams duration is a moving target.

state.name: seekableWindow
state.docs:
The length of the seekable window in seconds starting from `seekableStart` and ending at
`seekableEnd`.

state.name: seeking
state.docs: Whether media is actively seeking to a new playback position.

state.name: sources
state.docs:
The URL and optionally type of the current media resource/s to be considered for playback.
Use `source` to get the currently loaded resource.

state.name: source
state.docs: The chosen media resource. Defaults to `{ src: '', type: '' }` if no media has been loaded.

state.name: currentSrc
state.docs: Alias for `source`.

state.name: started
state.docs: Whether media playback has started. In other words it will be true if `currentTime > 0`.

state.name: streamType
state.docs:
The current media stream type. This value helps determine what type of UI should be
displayed and whether seeking operations are permitted during live streams. If seeking
is permitted, set this value to `live:dvr` or `ll-live:dvr`.

state.name: title
state.docs: The title of the current media.

state.name: textTracks
state.docs: The list of all available text tracks.

state.name: textTrack
state.docs: The current captions/subtitles text track that is showing.

state.name: viewType
state.docs:
The type of player view that should be used (i.e., audio or video). By default this is set
to `video`.

state.name: volume
state.docs: An `int` between `0` (silent) and `1` (loudest) indicating the audio volume. Defaults to `1`.

state.name: waiting
state.docs: Whether playback has temporarily stopped because of a lack of temporary data.

state.name: pointer
state.docs: The user's pointing device type.

state.name: orientation
state.docs: The current screen orientation.

state.name: width
state.docs: The width of the media player container in pixels.

state.name: height
state.docs: The height of the media player container in pixels.

state.name: mediaWidth
state.docs: The width of the media provider in pixels.

state.name: mediaHeight
state.docs: The height of the media in provider pixels.

props.name: provider

type.full: ({ type: 'audio'; } & AudioProvider) | ({ type: 'video'; } & VideoProvider) | ({ type: 'hls'; } & HLSProvider)

props.docs: The current media provider.

props.name: controls
props.docs: Media controls settings.

props.name: orientation
props.docs:
Controls the screen orientation of the current browser window and dispatches orientation
change events on the player.

props.name: qualities
props.docs: A list of all `VideoQuality` objects representing the set of available video renditions.

props.name: audioTracks
props.docs: A list of all `AudioTrack` objects representing the set of available audio tracks.

props.name: textTracks
props.docs: A list of all `TextTrack` objects representing the set of available text tracks.

props.name: textRenderers
props.docs:
Contains text renderers which are responsible for loading, parsing, and rendering text
tracks.

props.name: paused
props.docs:
Whether playback should be paused. Defaults to `true` if no media has loaded or playback has
not started. Setting this to `false` will begin/resume playback.

props.name: muted
props.docs: Whether the audio is muted or not.

props.name: currentTime
props.docs:
A `double` indicating the current playback time in seconds. Defaults to `0` if the media has
not started to play and has not seeked. Setting this value seeks the media to the new
time. The value can be set to a minimum of `0` and maximum of the total length of the
media (indicated by the duration prop).

props.name: volume
props.docs: An `int` between `0` (silent) and `1` (loudest) indicating the audio volume. Defaults to `1`.

props.name: playsinline
props.docs:
Whether the video is to be played "inline", that is within the element's playback area. Note
that setting this to `false` does not imply that the video will always be played in fullscreen.
Depending on the provider, changing this prop may cause the player to completely reset.

props.name: playbackRate
props.docs:
Sets the rate at which the media is being played back. This is used to implement user
controls for fast forward, slow motion, and so forth. The normal playback rate is multiplied
by this value to obtain the current rate, so a value of 1.0 indicates normal speed.

Examples:

- `0.5` = slow down to 50% of the normal speed
- `1.5` = speed up normal speed by 50%
- `2` = double the normal speed

props.name: state
props.docs: This object contains the current state of the component.

methods.name: play
methods.docs:
Begins/resumes playback of the media. If this method is called programmatically before the
user has interacted with the player, the promise may be rejected subject to the browser's
autoplay policies. This method will throw if called before media is ready for playback.

methods.name: pause
methods.docs:
Pauses playback of the media. This method will throw if called before media is ready for
playback.

methods.name: enterFullscreen
methods.docs:
Attempts to display the player in fullscreen. The promise will resolve if successful, and
reject if not. This method will throw if any fullscreen API is _not_ currently available.

methods.name: exitFullscreen
methods.docs:
Attempts to display the player inline by exiting fullscreen. This method will throw if any
fullscreen API is _not_ currently available.

methods.name: enterPictureInPicture
methods.docs:
Attempts to display the player in picture-in-picture mode. This method will throw if PIP is
not supported. This method will also return a `PictureInPictureWindow` if the current
provider supports it.

methods.name: exitPictureInPicture
methods.docs:
Attempts to display the player in inline by exiting picture-in-picture mode. This method
will throw if not supported.

methods.name: seekToLiveEdge
methods.docs:
Sets the current time to the live edge (i.e., `duration`). This is a no-op for non-live
streams and will throw if called before media is ready for playback.

methods.name: startLoading
methods.docs:
Called when media can begin loading. Calling this method will trigger the initial provider
loading process. Calling it more than once has no effect.

methods.name: matchQuery
methods.docs:
Returns a new `PlayerQueryList` object that can then be used to determine if the
player and document matches the query string, as well as to monitor any changes to detect
when it matches (or stops matching) that query.

A player query supports the same syntax as media queries and allows media state properties
to be used like so:

methods.name: subscribe
methods.docs: Subscribe to live updates of component state.

components.docs: Used to render the current provider.

props.name: state
props.docs: This object contains the current state of the component.

methods.name: subscribe
methods.docs: Subscribe to live updates of component state.

components.name: CaptionButton

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-active - Whether closed captions or subtitles are on.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive).

components.name: FullscreenButton

doctags.text: data-active - Whether fullscreen mode is active.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-supported - Whether fullscreen mode is supported.

props.name: target
props.docs:
The target element on which to request fullscreen on. The target can be `media`
(i.e., `<media-player>`) or `provider`. The `prefer-media` option will first see if the native
fullscreen API is available, if not it'll try the media provider.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive).

components.name: LiveButton
components.docs:
This component displays the current live status of the stream. This includes whether it's
live, at the live edge, or not live. In addition, when this button is pressed it will skip
ahead to the live edge.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-edge - Playback is at the live edge.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-hidden - Whether current media is _not_ live.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-focus - Whether button is being keyboard focused.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-hocus - Whether button is being keyboard focused or hovered over.

props.name: disabled
props.docs:
Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive). This will prevent seeking to the
live edge when pressed.

components.name: MuteButton
components.docs: A button for toggling the muted state of the player.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive).

components.name: PIPButton
components.docs: A button for toggling the picture-in-picture (PIP) mode of the player.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-supported - Whether picture-in-picture mode is available.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive).

components.name: PlayButton
components.docs: A button for toggling the playback state (play/pause) of the current media.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive).

components.name: SeekButton
components.docs: A button for seeking the current media playback forwards or backwards by a specified amount.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-seeking - Whether a seeking operation is in progress.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-supported - Whether seeking operations are permitted.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-focus - Whether button is being keyboard focused.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-hocus - Whether button is being keyboard focused or hovered over.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive).

props.name: seconds
props.docs:
The amount to seek the media playback forwards (positive number) or backwards (negative number)
when the seek button is pressed.

components.name: ToggleButton
components.docs: A toggle button is a two-state button that can be either off (not pressed) or on (pressed).

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-pressed - Whether the toggle is in an "on" state (pressed).

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-focus - Whether button is being keyboard focused.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-hocus - Whether button is being keyboard focused or hovered over.

props.name: defaultPressed
props.docs: Whether it should start in the on (pressed) state.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive).

props.name: pressed
props.docs: Whether the toggle is currently in a `pressed` state.

components.name: Captions
components.docs:
Renders and displays captions/subtitles. This will be an overlay for video and a simple
captions box for audio.

components.name: ControlsGroup
components.docs: This component creates a container for media controls.

components.name: Controls
components.docs: This component creates a container for control groups.

doctags.name: attr

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-fullscreen - Whether fullscreen mode is active.

props.name: hideDelay
props.docs:
The default amount of delay in milliseconds while media playback is progressing without user
activity to hide the controls.

events.name: change
events.docs: Fired when the active state of the controls change.

components.name: Gesture
components.docs: This component enables actions to be performed on the media based on user gestures.

props.name: event
props.docs:
The DOM event type that will trigger this gesture. It can be any valid DOM event type. Any
event can be prefixed with `dbl` to ensure it occurs twice in succession (max 200ms gap).

props.name: action
props.docs:
An action describes the type of media request event that will be dispatched, which will
ultimately perform some operation on the player.

components.name: MenuButton
components.docs:
A button that controls the opening and closing of a menu component. The button will become a
menuitem when used inside a submenu.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-focus - Whether button is being keyboard focused.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-hocus - Whether button is being keyboard focused or hovered over.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the button should be disabled (non-interactive).

events.name: select

components.name: MenuItem

Represents a specific option or action, typically displayed as a text label or icon, which
users can select to access or perform a particular function or view related content.

events.name: select

components.name: MenuItems

doctags.name: attr

doctags.name: attr

doctags.name: attr

props.name: placement

type.full: MenuPlacementSide | 'bottom start' | 'bottom center' | 'bottom end' | 'top start' | 'top center' | 'top end' | 'right start' | 'right center' | 'right end' | 'left start' | 'left center' | 'left end'

A space-separated list which specifies the side and alignment of the menu relative
to the menu button.

props.name: offset

The distance in pixels between the menu items and the menu button. You can also set
the CSS variable `--media-menu-y-offset` to adjust this offset.

props.name: alignOffset

the CSS variable `--media-menu-x-offset` to adjust this offset.

components.name: MenuPortal

inside.

props.name: disabled

Whether the portal should be disabled. The value can be the string "fullscreen" to disable
portals while media is fullscreen. This is to ensure the menu remains visible.

components.name: Menu

Root menu container used to hold and manage a menu button and menu items. This component is

components.name: SliderPreview
components.docs:
Used to provide users with a real-time or interactive preview of the value or selection they
are making as they move the slider thumb. This can include displaying the current pointer
value numerically, or displaying a thumbnail over the time slider.

props.docs:
The distance in pixels between the preview and the slider. You can also set
the CSS variable `--media-slider-preview-offset` to adjust this offset.

props.name: noClamp
props.docs:
By default, the preview will be clamped to the left and right of the slider track. If this
is set to `true`, the preview will flow outside of the container when at the edges.

components.name: SliderValue
components.docs:
Displays the specific numeric representation of the current or pointer value of the slider.
When a user interacts with a slider by moving its thumb along the track, the slider value
changes accordingly.

props.name: type
props.docs: Whether to use the slider's current value, or pointer value.

props.name: format
props.docs: Determines how the value is formatted.

props.name: showHours
props.docs:
Whether the time should always show the hours unit, even if the time is less than
1 hour. Only available if the `format` attribute is set to `time`.

props.name: padHours
props.docs:
Whether the hours unit should be padded with zeroes to a length of 2. Only available if
the `format` attribute is set to `time`.

props.name: padMinutes
props.docs:
Whether the minutes unit should be padded with zeroes to a length of 2. Only available if
the `format` attribute is set to `time`.

props.name: decimalPlaces
props.docs:
Round the value when formatted as a percentage to the given number of decimal places. Only
available if `format` attribute is `percent`.

methods.name: getValueText
methods.docs: Returns the current value formatted as text based on prop settings.

components.name: SliderVideo
components.docs:
Used to load a low-resolution video to be displayed when the user is hovering over or dragging
the time slider. The preview video will automatically be updated to be in-sync with the current
preview position, so ensure it has the same length as the original media (i.e., same duration).

events.name: can-play
events.docs:
Fired when the user agent can play the media, but estimates that **not enough** data has been
loaded to play the media up to its end without having to stop for further buffering of content.

events.name: error
events.docs:
Fired when media loading or playback has encountered any issues (for example, a network
connectivity problem). The event detail contains a potential message containing more
information about the error (empty string if nothing available), and a code that identifies
the general type of error that occurred.

components.name: Slider
components.docs:
Versatile and user-friendly input control designed for seamless cross-browser compatibility and
accessibility with ARIA support. It offers a smooth user experience for both mouse and touch
interactions and is highly customizable in terms of styling. Users can effortlessly input numeric
values within a specified range, defined by a minimum and maximum value.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-dragging - Whether slider thumb is being dragged.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-pointing - Whether user's pointing device is over slider.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-active - Whether slider is being interacted with.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-focus - Whether slider is being keyboard focused.

doctags.name: attr
doctags.text: data-hocus - Whether slider is being keyboard focused or hovered over.

props.name: min
props.docs: The lowest slider value in the range of permitted values.

props.name: max
props.docs: The greatest slider value in the range of permitted values.

props.name: value
props.docs: The current slider value.

props.name: disabled
props.docs: Whether the slider should be disabled (non-interactive).

props.name: orientation
props.docs: The orientation of the slider.

props.name: step
props.docs:
A number that specifies the granularity that the slider value must adhere to.

A step is an abstract unit that may carry a different type of measure depending on the type of
slider. For example, for the volume slider each step is 1% of volume, and for the time slider
it is 1 second which is a varying percentage depending on the media duration.

props.name: keyStep
props.docs:
♿ **ARIA:** A number that specifies the number of steps taken when interacting with
the slider via keyboard.

A step is an abstract unit that may carry different type of measure depending on the type of
slider. For example, for the volume slider each step is 1% of volume, and for the time slider
it is 1 second which is a varying percentage depending on the media duration.

props.name: shiftKeyMultiplier
props.docs:
♿ **ARIA:** A number that will be used to multiply the `keyStep` when the `Shift` key
is held down and the slider value is changed by pressing `LeftArrow` or `RightArrow`. Think
of it as `keyStep * shiftKeyMultiplier`.

events.name: drag-start
events.docs:
Fired when the user begins interacting with the slider and dragging the thumb. The event
detail contains the current value the drag is starting at.

events.name: drag-end
events.docs:
Fired when the user stops dragging the slider thumb. The event detail contains the value
the drag is ending at.

events.name: value-change
events.docs: Fired when the slider value changes. The event detail contains the current value.

events.name: drag-value-change
events.docs:
Fired when the slider drag value changes. The drag value indicates the last slider value that
the user has dragged to. The event detail contains the value.

events.name: pointer-value-change
events.docs:
Fired when the device pointer is inside the slider region and it's position changes. The
event detail contains the preview value. Do note, this includes touch, mouse, and keyboard
devices.

doctags.name: example
doctags.text:
```html
<!-- Forward +30s on each press. -->
<media-seek-button seconds="+30">
  <media-icon type="seek-forward"></media-icon>
</media-seek-button>
<!-- Backward -30s on each press. -->
<media-seek-button seconds="-30">
  <media-icon type="seek-backward"></media-icon>
</media-seek-button>
```
